problem: When written in standard form, how many zeroes are in the product $\left(9.2 \times 10^2\right)\left(8 \times 10^6\right)$?
solution: First, simplify $(9.2\times 10^2)(8\times 10^6)=73.6\times 10^8$.  The factor of $10^8$ instructs us to move the decimal point in 73.6 eight places to the right.  The first step moves the decimal past the 6 and the next $\boxed{7}$ steps each introduce a digit of 0.
model_solution:
Step 1: Multiply the coefficients $9.2$ and $8$.

$9.2 \times 8 = 73.6$
Step 2: When multiplying powers of 10, add the exponents.
$\left(9.2 \times 10^2\right)\left(8 \times 10^6\right)=73.6 \times 10^{2+6}=73.6 \times 10^8$
Step 3: Count the number of zeroes in the product $73.6 \times 10^8$.

$73.6 \times 10^8=7.36 \times 10^{10}$ 

There are 10 zeroes in $7.36 \times 10^{10}$.
There are 10 zeroes in the product.
Step 4: Count the number of zeroes in the product $7.36 \times 10^{10}$.
There are 10 zeroes in $7.36 \times 10^{10}$.
There are 10 zeroes in the product $7.36 \times 10^{10}$.
There are 10 zeroes in the product.
